TITLE: Quiet Awards Season Has Hollywood Uneasy
SUMMARY: Audiences remain reluctant to return to theaters. And the kinds of movies that used to rely on the sheen of awards to attract moviegoers now find themselves in peril.

TITLE: Your Head of H.R. Is Now Basically the School Nurse
SUMMARY: Vaccine mandates. Boosters. Exemptions. Testing protocol. Just a handful of public health questions that human resources departments now have to answer.

TITLE: The Week in Business: Vaccine Mandates
SUMMARY: Job growth stalled. Awards season fizzled. And confirmation hearings for President Biden’s nominees for the two top Fed posts are coming up.

TITLE: U.S. Sues Shop Owner Who Dumped 91,500 Pennies on Ex-Worker’s Driveway
SUMMARY: The Labor Department said the owner of a Georgia auto-repair shop had retaliated against the former employee for reporting that he had not received his final paycheck.

TITLE: Robert Birnbaum, Architect of Modern-Day Financial Markets, Dies at 94
SUMMARY: He was renowned for his steady hand during the 1987 stock market crash. He later helped design circuit breakers to calm future panics.

TITLE: Why Tesla Soared as Other Automakers Struggled to Make Cars
SUMMARY: The yawning disparity between the performance of the electric car company and established automakers last year reflects the technological change roiling the industry.

TITLE: No More Working for Jerks!
SUMMARY: For almost two years, couches have been cubicles. Colleagues are instant message avatars. And people are reconsidering how much they should have to put up with from a boss.

TITLE: College Merit Aid (or Lack Thereof) Makes Early Decision Ever Murkier
SUMMARY: Northeastern University won’t estimate how much merit aid it might offer if you get in. Can schools make you enroll if they don’t give you enough?

TITLE: Why Stock Investors Need to Look a Decade Ahead, at Lea
SUMMARY: In this season for forecasts and resolutions, investors will be better off if they are able to think 10 or more years ahead, our columnist says.

TITLE: Sara Menker and Gro Intelligence Are Tackling Global Hunger
SUMMARY: The Ethiopian entrepreneur Sara Menker founded Gro Intelligence, which uses artificial intelligence to forecast global agricultural trends and battle food insecurity.

TITLE: How Many Bagels Does It Take to Keep a Place in Business?
SUMMARY: Two quintessential bagel shops dish on the business of selling lots and lots of bagels.

TITLE: What’s Next for the Deal Boom?
SUMMARY: After a record year of transactions in 2021, deal makers are expecting a slowdown in 2022. Here are three factors that could intensify it.

TITLE: Airlines Strand Passengers Who Partied on Flight Without Masks
SUMMARY: A group of Canadian social media influencers and others flouted Covid-19 rules on a flight to Cancún, Mexico, resulting in airlines leaving many of them without a way home.

TITLE: Federal Rental Assistance Is Running Out, With Tenants Still in Need
SUMMARY: An announcement from the Treasury Department on Friday revealed that there was less money available for renters than some states had hoped.

TITLE: What Are Your Questions About Inflation?
SUMMARY: Times reporters want to answer your questions about where inflation is likely to go and how it may affect your life.

TITLE: Citigroup Prepares to Fire Unvaccinated Workers at the End of January
SUMMARY: The bank is said to have given all its U.S. staff until Jan. 14 to submit proof of inoculations, and workers who do not comply will be placed on leave and fired on Jan. 31.

TITLE: The Tao of the Yeezy Gap x Balenciaga Project
SUMMARY: No products have been announced yet, but there’s already a lot to unpack.

TITLE: Biden Administration Warns Against Spyware Targeting Dissidents
SUMMARY: The U.S. intelligence community offered steps that would mitigate — but not stop — spyware developed by firms like the NSO Group.

TITLE: Ron Perelman's Debts Come Due
SUMMARY: Ron Perelman seemed to have everything. Until the bill arrived.

TITLE: Tax Season 2022: What to Know About Child Credit and Stimulus Payments
SUMMARY: First, look in your mailbox for two letters the I.R.S. is sending this month. Make sure the numbers the agency is listing for pandemic aid match yours.

TITLE: As Unemployment Falls, Interest Rate Increases Creep Nearer
SUMMARY: The jobless rate is falling sharply and pay is jumping. That may increase the urgency as the Federal Reserve withdraws economic support.

TITLE: Eurozone Inflation Rises to 5 Percent, Highest on Record
SUMMARY: A small consolation: Energy prices rose 26 percent in December from a year earlier, a slightly slower pace than the previous month.

TITLE: New York Could Make History With a Fashion Sustainability Act
SUMMARY: The state would be the first to pass legislation setting broad sustainability regulations for the industry.

TITLE: Airlines, Reeling From Omicron, Push E.U. to Ease Rules on Airport Slots
SUMMARY: The airlines say they are being forced to fly thousands of nearly empty flights to satisfy rules requiring the use of landing and takeoff slots at airports.

TITLE: Biden’s Vaccine Mandates Hit the High Court
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court will consider challenges to the policies today.

TITLE: December Jobs Report: U.S. Added 199,000 Jobs
SUMMARY: The gain of 199,000 was the weakest of the year, but not for lack of demand: The unemployment rate fell to 3.9 percent, and wages increased.

TITLE: Conservative Majority on Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Biden's Vaccine Plan
SUMMARY: The court seemed more likely to sustain a separate requirement that health care workers at facilities that receive federal money be vaccinated.

TITLE: Un país entero exige hablar con el gerente
SUMMARY: En tiempos de enojo y frustración, las personas se comportan como niños haciendo pataletas cada vez que enfrentan pequeñas decepciones al comprar o viajar.

TITLE: Lawsuit says Meta shares blame in the killing of a federal guard.
SUMMARY: A lawsuit argued that individuals who sought to harm law enforcement officers were able to connect with one another on Facebook.

TITLE: Scientists Endorse Covid Boosters, But to a Point
SUMMARY: Everyone should get a booster shot. In the long run, though, doses every few months aren’t a viable public health strategy, scientists say.

TITLE: Kazakhstan’s Bitcoin Mining Industry Is Upended by Unrest
SUMMARY: After the country’s largest telecommunications company shut off internet access throughout the country on Wednesday, processing activity on Bitcoin plunged.

TITLE: Companies Donated Millions to Those Who Voted to Overturn Biden's Win
SUMMARY: One year after the Capitol riot, many businesses resumed corporate donations to lawmakers who voted against certifying the 2020 election.

TITLE: New York Times Co. to Buy The Athletic for $550 Million in Cash
SUMMARY: The deal could help the media company reach its goal of 10 million subscriptions ahead of schedule.

TITLE: Covid Treatments Including Paxlovid Are Rationed as Cases Spike
SUMMARY: Scarce supplies and surging Covid cases have caused health officials, hospitals, doctors and patients to scramble for pills and infusions.

TITLE: That Expensive Bourbon You Bought May Be a Fake
SUMMARY: Counterfeiting — filling luxury bottles with cheap liquor — has hit American whiskey hard as sky-high prices raise the payoff for scammers.

TITLE: How Corporate America Has Changed After the Capitol Riot
SUMMARY: Business leaders promised a reckoning after the Jan. 6 riots. They’ve altered some practices, and returned to others.

TITLE: A Custom Mercury, With a Batmobile in Its Family Tree, Heads to Auction
SUMMARY: The “Hirohata Merc,” commissioned in 1952 and one of the most famous custom cars of its era, is up for sale for the first time in over 60 years.

TITLE: Cruise Ships Are Still Sailing as Cases Rise and Criticism Mounts
SUMMARY: One day after the C.D.C. advised against all travel on cruise ships, thousands of cruisers partied like it was 2019. But worries about onboard policies — and frustration over quarantines — are rising.

TITLE: A Fed Official’s 2020 Trade Drew Outcry. It Went Further Than First Disclosed.
SUMMARY: Corrected disclosures show that Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida sold a stock fund, then swiftly repurchased it before a big Fed announcement.

TITLE: Starbucks Union Workers Near Buffalo Walk Out Over Covid Concerns
SUMMARY: The walkout, involving about half a dozen employees, is planned to last the rest of the week.

TITLE: Federal Labor Officials Claim New York Times Violated Workplace Law
SUMMARY: The National Labor Relations Board alleges that Times management wrongly prevented some employees from showing support for a union, a claim the paper denied.

TITLE: F.B.I. Arrests Man Accused of Stealing Unpublished Book Manuscripts
SUMMARY: Filippo Bernardini, an Italian citizen who worked in publishing, was charged with wire fraud and identity theft for a scheme that prosecutors said affected hundreds of people over five or more years.

TITLE: Slate’s Top Editor, Jared Hohlt, Leaves After a Three-Year Run
SUMMARY: Jared Hohlt, who made his reputation at New York magazine, led the publication’s newsroom during a difficult period for digital media.

TITLE: Fed Officials Discussed Raising Rates Sooner and Faster, Minutes Show
SUMMARY: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting show that officials are contemplating when and how quickly to lift interest rates.

TITLE: The Oscars Want Crowd-Pleasers, but Where Are the Crowds?
SUMMARY: As contenders like “West Side Story” and “Belfast” struggle for audiences, can a blockbuster like “Spider-Man: No Way Home” swing into the Oscar race?

TITLE: Barbie and Balmain Want to Make Toys the Next Big Fashion Frontier
SUMMARY: The first high-fashion collaboration of the year is here, and it’s surprisingly good.

TITLE: HBO Max and HBO Hit 73.8 million Subscribers, Topping Company Forecast
SUMMARY: The announcement represents a vindication of the strategy to release the entire Warner Bros. 2021 film slate simultaneously in theaters and on streaming.

TITLE: William M. Ellinghaus Dies at 99; Presided Over AT&T Breakup
SUMMARY: He led the communications giant when it settled an antitrust suit in the 1980s, not long after he helped save New York City in the fiscal crisis of the ’70s.

TITLE: Audie Cornish, Host of ‘All Things Considered,’ Is Leaving NPR
SUMMARY: Her decision follows the recent exits of other prominent people of color at the public broadcaster.

TITLE: Is It Time for Big In-Person Events Again? Organizers Are Divided
SUMMARY: Some big events are delaying their return to in-person gatherings, but the organizers of CES, the Winter Olympics and the Australian Open have decided it’s time to gather in person again.

TITLE: Quentin Tarantino to Sell ‘Pulp Fiction’ NFTs, Defying Miramax Suit
SUMMARY: The director’s fight over ownership of the movie’s script could set a legal precedent for intellectual property rights.

TITLE: CES Will Test an Appetite for Live Events in the Pandemic
SUMMARY: Organizers insist that the conference, which formally kicks off today, had to return in-person.

TITLE: As Beijing Takes Control, Chinese Tech Companies Lose Jobs and Hope
SUMMARY: The crackdown is killing the entrepreneurial drive that made China a tech power and destroying jobs that used to attract the country’s brightest.

TITLE: Organic Milk Farmers in Northeast Under Pressure as Processors Look West
SUMMARY: Organic milk has been a lifeline for small farms in Maine and other New England states. Now those farms are facing trouble as milk processors look to huge dairies in Western states.

TITLE: Supply Chain Woes Prompt a New Push to Revive U.S. Factories
SUMMARY: Companies are testing whether the United States can regain some of the manufacturing output it ceded in recent decades to China and other countries.

TITLE: Sony Moves Toward Electric Car Market With a New Subsidiary
SUMMARY: Japan’s electronics giant introduced a new version of a prototype S.U.V. that runs on batteries.

TITLE: PG&E equipment is blamed for starting the Dixie Fire in Northern California.
SUMMARY: Fire investigators referred their findings to prosecutors.
